user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete:
```c
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in the provided code. The function body uses only standard C constructs (if/else, assignment, function calls, pointer dereference). The only potentially noteworthy token is the macro definition shown in the additional code: #define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0}) — this uses a compound literal, which is part of standard C99 (not a compiler extension). There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm, __declspec, typeof (GCC), statement expressions ({ ... } GNU extension returning value), inline assembly, pragma GCC/Clang/MSVC diagnostics, or other vendor-specific builtins. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 as stated (which asks to report only explicit compiler extensions). Note: if the project enforces only pre-C99 (C89) language subset, the compound literal would be unsupported by that older standard — but that is a missing language feature, not a compiler-specific extension; per the rule given, it is not an explicit compiler extension to report here.
